this is stupid. basically, in order for fat to burn, you need over 30~40 minutes of exercise. also, high intensity exercise consume glucose rather than fat, you need moderate or low mid intensity with over 30~40 minutes of exercise in order to lose fat. Also, high intensity exercise increase reactive oxygen which makes you age.
so walking which is less intensive than running or other sports, which has less injury probability or impact (like knees), which can be done easily over 30~40 minutes is a good choice of cardio exercise for people. there are scientific evidence for walking over 7000 steps a day (10000 a bit excessive) which benefits cardio, circulation etc

Ok, Scishow and people reading this comment, please understand I'm not trying to throw shade here. I don't typically like to comment in general, let alone on these things. That being said, here is a semi-long winded response. *Quick disclaimer, I don't claim to be a spokes person for any of these institutions or groups, however I do belong to the ACSM.* 10,000 steps. Do we need it? You answered the question partially. It's a lot harder than a yes or no answer. There is some statistical evidence that 10,000 steps a day will reduce the chances of a cardiovascular event {Kraus, W. E., & Janz, K. F. (2019). Daily Step Counts for Measuring Physical Activity Exposure and Its Relation to Health. Official Journal of the College of Sports Medicine, 1206–1212.} Not only that, but it's a relatively easy number to remember and can be effectively communicated to the masses as an easier way to meet the US Health Guidelines of weekly activity needed for adults { Le-Masurier, G. C., Sidman, C. L., & Corbin, C. B. (2003). Accumulating 10,000 Steps: Does this Meet Current Physical Activity Guidelines? Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport, 74, 389–394.} The problem you're trying to solve in this video is "does it actually work biologically?" but neglecting "does it actually work socially?". 10,000 steps through some of these studies shows that this number is significant enough to achieve the daily and weekly recommended exercise guidelines. This isn't supported by metadata, but I can tell you as someone who works in this field that it's a lot more effective to tell patients/clients to work 10,000 steps daily into life then it is to get them to engage in purposeful exercise. I'm not the only one who has seen this, however I will say this is anecdotal evidence as I can't find a study on purposeful exercise vs step counts and the adherence rate thereof. So what am I trying to say? The TL;DR of this comment is to help you realize that 10,000 steps isn't necessarily wrong when it comes to cardiac health, HOWEVER it is easier in my personal experience to effectively communicate and keep adherence to 10,000 steps daily as enough exercise than it is to get clients/patients to do purposeful exercise. It's a fallback answer. Yes, exercise is great and I encourage you to do it! But if you refuse, at least get 10,000 steps a day to meet close to daily health guidelines established in the second cited article. Thanks guys, sorry for the long comment. Wanted to throw my two cents in.

I find this episode disappointing compared to the usual standard of Scishow. It neglects to mention 2 important things.
1) You get more health benefits from doing more exercise. The minimum recommendation is just that, a minimum, so that you don't significantly increase your chances of bad health outcomes compared to the average of the population. But the more you exercise over that, the better your health will be! (up to a certain point that the vast majority of people will never reach anyway). Also if you're a relatively young person (<60), you should probably do more than the minimum, so that you can actually do the minimum once you're older.
2) A 4 km/h walk is... the minimum of the minimum. An average person is barely just at 3 METs at that speed, and that's the lower end of moderate exercise. Moderate exercise goes up to 6 METs, which is twice as intense!


So yeah, there may be no real science behind the figure of 10000 steps itself, but the video kind of omitted to mention that there's certainly plenty behind the fact that more physical activity = better overall health!

Thank you for pointing out how problematic this standard can be. Physically disabled athlete here. I walk most of the time and even still, ten thousand steps is usually way too me due to my weird gait. Five thousand is probably more right as far as what I can generally manage. I much prefer to swim or play wheelchair basketball or ride a horse or sit ski, or to do just about anything not related to walking, for exercise. It's nice to hear someone echo what I've always known because as a disabled person, I sometimes find that this 'rule' can worm its way into my head and create worry and doubt and things, even though I workout almost every day. My health should not be worse just because my arms do some of the work my legs might do sometimes. I feel better, even if I already knew this before now. Validation.

Counting your steps shouldn't really be considered activity unless you are jogging, running or doing something that undoubtedly gets your heart rate up. If you count the steps that you take while you are grocery shopping that doesn't count. Counting steps to stay healthy is not accurate unless you dedicate the time for it. For example during your 15 min breaks you walk briskly to get your heart rate up, that can be a good step count towards fitness. If your work is strenuous and your heart rate is elevated then sure, the steps could count then too. Just remember this is a bare minimum to recieve small health benefits. 30 mins of moderate to vigorous exercise 3 times a week is way better than just counting your steps. Use counting you steps as an entry to beginning to jog and then later to run (or you can stick with jogging) and then later something else. If you already hit 20,000 steps a day I challenge you to start jogging for 10 minutes a day, and then increase. Take care and Get Action.

I recently started a job that requires me to be at a desk at least 6 a day. The city it's located in is pretty dangerous, so going for a walk after work isn't a good idea. Instead, I unplugged a nearby portable heater, turned on its side and braced it against the desk, and have been using as a makeshift aerobic step platform. Now I exercise in between clients. I do 1000 step ups with knee raises per leg, and then another 1000 side step ups with knee raises per leg. I'm already seeing a difference; I dropped 5 lbs last week. My coworkers just kind of awkwardly stared at first, but later admitted that it was a cool idea.

Knowing a physical therapist (and significant knowledge of the field, even if I wouldn't claim to be one), I wont say that SciShow is wrong, but many would argue that 10000 steps isn't an unreasonable goal for your health. I've heard of the 15000 a week of speed running, but many people don't have the time for that. So 2/3 of that goal at low exercise a day (or almost 5x that a week) is a reasonable compromise. This just helps people to be somewhat active and move more. So no, 10000 steps wont automatically turn you into a fit and healthy person, but it is a good goal to help keep your overall health in the positive. So even if SciShow say that 10000 is a meaningless number, it is somewhat enough to get your body to where it should be. If you can incorporate that with some moderate or heavy exercise, you are so much closer to living a fit and healthy life.
